bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Richard Curle, 1883-1968, was an author, traveler and bibliophile. In his early career he wrote leaders for such newspapers as the Pretoria News (South Africa), The Rangoon Times (Burma), and The Daily Mail (London). He also wrote articles for other newspapers and magazines, short stories, and books of fiction and non-fiction. In 1912 Curle was introduced to Joseph Conrad and, as a consequence of their long-standing friendship, much of Curle's writings and correspondence with colleagues and friends reflects his considerable knowledge of Conrad and his works.

Lady Margaret Brooke, 1849-1936, was a writer and queen consort of the White Rajah of Sarawak. Born Margaret Alice Lili de Windt in England, she married the second White Rajah of Sarawak, Charles Brooke, in 1869, becoming the first Ranee, or "queen," of the region by marriage. She wrote a memoir about her life as queen titled My Time in Sarawak (1913) and enjoyed the company of many famous English writers once she returned to England after the birth of her last three children.
Nigel Maxwell was a bibliographer who worked to compile The Dictionary of the Works of Joseph Conrad.

J.M. (John Mackinnon) Robertson, 1856-1933, was a prolific writer, journalist, and member of Parliament. Over the course of his career he worked as an editor and writer for the Edinburgh Evening News and London's National Reformer. He was a member of the Liberal party, a secularist, and a supporter of free trade and rationalism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Curle mss. III, 1904-1967, consists primarily of letters to author Richard Curle, 1883-1968, from Lady Margaret Alice Lilly (de Windt) Brooke, Ranee of Sarawak, 1849-1936; bibliographer Nigel Maxwell; and journalist John Mackinnon Robertson, 1856-1933.

Margaret of Sarawak's letters date from 1923-1930 and consist primarily of social notes and family news, but they also contain comments on author William Henry Hudson (about whom Curle was preparing a book) and on Joseph Conrad.

Nigel Maxwell's correspondence, 1963-1967, concerns the preparation and publication of his Dictionary of the Works of Joseph Conrad and includes some copies of Curle's letters to him offering advice and corrections.
Robertson's letters are generally of a literary or personal nature with frequent comments on Curle's writings and on Conrad and Ivan Sergeevich Turgenev as writers.
Typescript copies of Joseph Conrad's letters to Richard Curle, 1912-1924, complete the collection.
